Mantle on 22 May 1963 hit one in the old Yankee stadium they said was still rising when it hit the concrete facade left a mark in it and bounced all the way back to the infield. They were able to get the exact height and distance. Some estimates at the time said it would have gone over 600ft, maybe 660ft.

More recently, I saw an estimate of that shot that was not nearly that far, but it was based on a false assumption. He assumed it left the bat at 122mph.
He assumed Mantle could not hit one out of Yankee Stadium because he never did, wrong!
He did hit them out during batting practice a number of times. This was documented in the Book "Explosion" by Mark Gallagher.

Mantle said he was tired of the extra innings (13th inning…..BTW, I was watching on the game on TV) and he was going for it. So, he was swinging from his heals, caught it perfectly. Batting practice ball comes in at maybe 70mph, he hit a fastball so figure 90 or more? They needed to calculate with those assumptions.

﴿قالَ رَبِّ أَنّى يَكونُ لي غُلامٌ وَقَد بَلَغَنِيَ الكِبَرُ وَامرَأَتي عاقِرٌ قالَ كَذلِكَ اللَّهُ يَفعَلُ ما يَشاءُ﴾ [آل عمران: ٤٠]
He said, "My Lord, how will I have a boy when I have reached old age and my wife is barren?" He [the angel] said, "Such is Allāh; He does what He wills."
- Saheeh International

﴿قالَ رَبِّ اجعَل لي آيَةً قالَ آيَتُكَ أَلّا تُكَلِّمَ النّاسَ ثَلاثَةَ أَيّامٍ إِلّا رَمزًا وَاذكُر رَبَّكَ كَثيرًا وَسَبِّح بِالعَشِيِّ وَالإِبكارِ﴾ [آل عمران: ٤١]
He said, "My Lord, make for me a sign." He said, "Your sign is that you will not [be able to] speak to the people for three days except by gesture. And remember your Lord much and exalt [Him with praise] in the evening and the morning."
- Saheeh International

﴿وَإِذ قالَتِ المَلائِكَةُ يا مَريَمُ إِنَّ اللَّهَ اصطَفاكِ وَطَهَّرَكِ وَاصطَفاكِ عَلى نِساءِ العالَمينَ﴾ [آل عمران: ٤٢]
And [mention] when the angels said, "O Mary, indeed Allāh has chosen you and purified you and chosen you above the women of the worlds.
- Saheeh International

﴿يا مَريَمُ اقنُتي لِرَبِّكِ وَاسجُدي وَاركَعي مَعَ الرّاكِعينَ﴾ [آل عمران: ٤٣]
O Mary, be devoutly obedient to your Lord and prostrate and bow with those who bow [in prayer]."
- Saheeh International

﴿ذلِكَ مِن أَنباءِ الغَيبِ نوحيهِ إِلَيكَ وَما كُنتَ لَدَيهِم إِذ يُلقونَ أَقلامَهُم أَيُّهُم يَكفُلُ مَريَمَ وَما كُنتَ لَدَيهِم إِذ يَختَصِمونَ﴾ [آل عمران: ٤٤]
That is from the news of the unseen which We reveal to you, [O Muḥammad]. And you were not with them when they cast their pens as to which of them should be responsible for Mary. Nor were you with them when they disputed.
- Saheeh International

﴿إِذ قالَتِ المَلائِكَةُ يا مَريَمُ إِنَّ اللَّهَ يُبَشِّرُكِ بِكَلِمَةٍ مِنهُ اسمُهُ المَسيحُ عيسَى ابنُ مَريَمَ وَجيهًا فِي الدُّنيا وَالآخِرَةِ وَمِنَ المُقَرَّبينَ﴾ [آل عمران: ٤٥]
[And mention] when the angels said, "O Mary, indeed Allāh gives you good tidings of a word from Him, whose name will be the Messiah, Jesus, the son of Mary - distinguished in this world and the Hereafter and among those brought near [to Allāh].
- Saheeh International

﴿وَيُكَلِّمُ النّاسَ فِي المَهدِ وَكَهلًا وَمِنَ الصّالِحينَ﴾ [آل عمران: ٤٦]
He will speak to the people in the cradle and in maturity and will be of the righteous."
- Saheeh International

﴿قالَت رَبِّ أَنّى يَكونُ لي وَلَدٌ وَلَم يَمسَسني بَشَرٌ قالَ كَذلِكِ اللَّهُ يَخلُقُ ما يَشاءُ إِذا قَضى أَمرًا فَإِنَّما يَقولُ لَهُ كُن فَيَكونُ﴾ [آل عمران: ٤٧]
She said, "My Lord, how will I have a child when no man has touched me?" [The angel] said, "Such is Allāh; He creates what He wills. When He decrees a matter, He only says to it, 'Be,' and it is.
- Saheeh International

﴿وَيُعَلِّمُهُ الكِتابَ وَالحِكمَةَ وَالتَّوراةَ وَالإِنجيلَ﴾ [آل عمران: ٤٨]
And He will teach him writing and wisdom and the Torah and the Gospel
- Saheeh International

﴿وَرَسولًا إِلى بَني إِسرائيلَ أَنّي قَد جِئتُكُم بِآيَةٍ مِن رَبِّكُم أَنّي أَخلُقُ لَكُم مِنَ الطّينِ كَهَيئَةِ الطَّيرِ فَأَنفُخُ فيهِ فَيَكونُ طَيرًا بِإِذنِ اللَّهِ وَأُبرِئُ الأَكمَهَ وَالأَبرَصَ وَأُحيِي المَوتى بِإِذنِ اللَّهِ وَأُنَبِّئُكُم بِما تَأكُلونَ وَما تَدَّخِرونَ في بُيوتِكُم إِنَّ في ذلِكَ لَآيَةً لَكُم إِن كُنتُم مُؤمِنينَ﴾ [آل عمران: ٤٩]
And [make him] a messenger to the Children of Israel, [who will say], 'Indeed I have come to you with a sign from your Lord in that I design for you from clay [that which is] like the form of a bird, then I breathe into it and it becomes a bird by permission of Allāh. And I cure the blind [from birth] and the leper, and I give life to the dead - by permission of Allāh. And I inform you of what you eat and what you store in your houses. Indeed in that is a sign for you, if you are believers.
- Saheeh International

﴿وَمُصَدِّقًا لِما بَينَ يَدَيَّ مِنَ التَّوراةِ وَلِأُحِلَّ لَكُم بَعضَ الَّذي حُرِّمَ عَلَيكُم وَجِئتُكُم بِآيَةٍ مِن رَبِّكُم فَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ وَأَطيعونِ﴾ [آل عمران: ٥٠]
And [I have come] confirming what was before me of the Torah and to make lawful for you some of what was forbidden to you. And I have come to you with a sign from your Lord, so fear Allāh and obey me.
- Saheeh International

﴿إِنَّ اللَّهَ رَبّي وَرَبُّكُم فَاعبُدوهُ هذا صِراطٌ مُستَقيمٌ﴾ [آل عمران: ٥١]
Indeed, Allāh is my Lord and your Lord, so worship Him. That is the straight path.'"
- Saheeh International

﴿قُل هُوَ اللَّهُ أَحَدٌ﴾ [الإخلاص: ١]
Say, "He is Allāh, [who is] One,
- Saheeh International

﴿اللَّهُ الصَّمَدُ﴾ [الإخلاص: ٢]
Allāh, the Eternal Refuge.
- Saheeh International

﴿لَم يَلِد وَلَم يولَد﴾ [الإخلاص: ٣]
He neither begets nor is born,

﴿وَلَم يَكُن لَهُ كُفُوًا أَحَدٌ﴾ [الإخلاص: ٤]
Nor is there to Him any equivalent."
- Saheeh International

﴿وَما خَلَقتُ الجِنَّ وَالإِنسَ إِلّا لِيَعبُدونِ﴾ [الذاريات: ٥٦]
And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me.
- Saheeh International

﴿ما أُريدُ مِنهُم مِن رِزقٍ وَما أُريدُ أَن يُطعِمونِ﴾ [الذاريات: ٥٧]
I do not want from them any provision, nor do I want them to feed Me.
- Saheeh International

﴿إِنَّ اللَّهَ هُوَ الرَّزّاقُ ذُو القُوَّةِ المَتينُ﴾ [الذاريات: ٥٨]
Indeed, it is Allāh who is the [continual] Provider, the firm possessor of strength.

﴿فَإِنَّ لِلَّذينَ ظَلَموا ذَنوبًا مِثلَ ذَنوبِ أَصحابِهِم فَلا يَستَعجِلونِ﴾ [الذاريات: ٥٩]
And indeed, for those who have wronged is a portion [of punishment] like the portion of their companions [i.e., predecessors], so let them not impatiently urge Me.

Destin- In reference the Audible "Skunk Works"- A few years back, we had a guest speaker at our annual Cristmas Banquet for the 8th Air Force Historical Society MN Chapter (an organization of WWII combat air crews, Naval and Marine avistors, POW's Korean War, Vietnam War , first and second Gulf War vets and guys like me).
The speaker was Bill Fox, who worked with Kelly Johnson at the Lockheed Skunk Works on the SR71.
It was an incredible hour + presentation!!!!
One of the most interesting nuggets he shared was that the plane was built using titanium, he told us the largest supplier of titanium in the world was the USSR.
He and we reveled in the irony and also how America got the titanium.
And the last photo he showed us was a picture of him, outside a hangar with a multi-colored plane in the background.
The plane/project was titled "Have Blue".
Oh...and a friend of mine was a F-117 driver who tokk a few trips to downtown Baghdad.
And I asked him why the plane was an F instead a B-117 as it was not a fighter but a bomber.
He said it was a marketing move by the Air Force.
The plane was a single seat bomber and they needed fighter pilots to fly it.
And he said "No self respecting fighter jock would even consider piloting a bomber. So they designated "THE Plane" F-117 but never told the prospective pilots it was a bomber until they committed to the program." And the lead in was "Hey...we have a really cool, top secret deal we think you'd be interested in but we can't tell you anything about it. You in?"
And of course, Wes was in.

You've probably already considered this, but, if you add some dense padding to the anchor points you may have better luck with everything. Allowing for about an inch of travel between the two points. Taking into account the flesh and bone of a human batter, letting mostly the momentum of the bat do the work. The human batter has a firm grip on the bat but a softer grip with more flexibility through his hands and arms. Taking this into account when designing the anchor points I think you would get the ball to travel further than without and less bat breakage. Maybe the just the arms of the machine could be made of a more flexible material for the same result?

One can see pretty clearly at about 4:45 that the wooden bat struck the ball not along the grain, but against it. This is the typical cause of wooden bats breaking. For this reason, ballplayers hold their bats in such a way that when they swing, the bat strikes the ball along the grain, and not against it. The direction of the grain on a bat is indicated by the placement of the label: if one holds the label towards oneself while gripping the bat, the ball will strike the bat along the grain, substantially reducing the likelihood that the bat will break.

I have no training in physics, so I don't know how to explain this in a technically proficient way. But the idea is something like this. Take a (not too thick) paperback book, and hold the front cover toward you, pressing your finger in the center of the cover. What you are doing here is applying force to the book against the 'grain' of the pages. Note how much force it takes to make the book bend. Now hold it on its side, with its spine facing you, and apply pressure to the spine of the book - along the 'grain' of the pages. You will note that it takes far more force to make the book bend in this way. Now imagine that the pages are held together rigidly, as in the structure of wood, and you will start to see why a bat held so that it strikes the ball against the grain will break far more easily than a bat held so that it strikes the ball along the grain.

I don't know whether a properly-aligned wooden bat could withstand the stresses of this machine, but this bat was certainly not properly aligned.

It seems to me that the limiting factor is the stress the bat can take before it breaks. I saw that in your vid with wooden bats. If you put a hinge on the part that holds the bat to allow it to swing (like the arms on a hammer mill) you will reduce the stress on the bat handle and allow it  to be swung much faster. what humans think is impossible.


Yellow, black. Yellow, black.
Yellow, black. Yellow, black.


Ooh, black and yellow!
Let's shake it up a little.


Barry! Breakfast is ready!


Ooming!


Hang on a second.


Hello?


- Barry?
- Adam?


- Oan you believe this is happening?
- I can't. I'll pick you up.


Looking sharp.


Use the stairs. Your father
paid good money for those.


Sorry. I'm excited.


Here's the graduate.
We're very proud of you, son.


A perfect report card, all B's.


Very proud.


Ma! I got a thing going here.


- You got lint on your fuzz.
- Ow! That's me!


- Wave to us! We'll be in row 118,000.
- Bye!


Barry, I told you,
stop flying in the house!


- Hey, Adam.
- Hey, Barry.


- Is that fuzz gel?
- A little. Special day, graduation.


Never thought I'd make it.


Three days grade school,
three days high school.


Those were awkward.


Three days college. I'm glad I took
a day and hitchhiked around the hive.


You did come back different.


- Hi, Barry.
- Artie, growing a mustache? Looks good.


- Hear about Frankie?
- Yeah.


- You going to the funeral?
- No, I'm not going.


Everybody knows,
sting someone, you die.


Don't waste it on a squirrel.
Such a hothead.


I guess he could have
just gotten out of the way.


I love this incorporating
an amusement park into our day.


That's why we don't need vacations.


Boy, quite a bit of pomp...
under the circumstances.


- Well, Adam, today we are men.
- We are!


- Bee-men.
- Amen!


Hallelujah!


Students, faculty, distinguished bees,


please welcome Dean Buzzwell.


Welcome, New Hive Oity
graduating class of...


...9:15.


That concludes our ceremonies.


And begins your career
at Honex Industries!


Will we pick ourjob today?


I heard it's just orientation.


Heads up! Here we go.


Keep your hands and antennas
inside the tram at all times.


- Wonder what it'll be like?
- A little scary.


Welcome to Honex,
a division of Honesco


and a part of the Hexagon Group.


This is it!


Wow.


Wow.


We know that you, as a bee,
have worked your whole life


to get to the point where you
can work for your whole life.


Honey begins when our valiant Pollen
Jocks bring the nectar to the hive.


Our top-secret formula


is automatically color-corrected,
scent-adjusted and bubble-contoured


into this soothing sweet syrup


with its distinctive
golden glow you know as...


Honey!


- That girl was hot.
- She's my cousin!


- She is?
- Yes, we're all cousins.


- Right. You're right.
- At Honex, we constantly strive


to improve every aspect
of bee existence.


These bees are stress-testing
a new helmet technology.


- What do you think he makes?
- Not enough.


Here we have our latest advancement,
the Krelman.


- What does that do?
- Oatches that little strand of honey


that hangs after you pour it.
Saves us millions.


Oan anyone work on the Krelman?


Of course. Most bee jobs are
small ones. But bees know


that every small job,
if it's done well, means a lot.


But choose carefully


because you'll stay in the job
you pick for the rest of your life.


The same job the rest of your life?
I didn't know that.


What's the difference?


You'll be happy to know that bees,
as a species, haven't had one day off


in 27 million years.


So you'll just work us to death?


We'll sure try.


Wow! That blew my mind!


"What's the difference?"
How can you say that?


One job forever?
That's an insane choice to have to make.


I'm relieved. Now we only have
to make one decision in life.


But, Adam, how could they
never have told us that?


Why would you question anything?
We're bees.


We're the most perfectly
functioning society on Earth.


You ever think maybe things
work a little too well here?


Like what? Give me one example.


I don't know. But you know
what I'm talking about.


Please clear the gate.
Royal Nectar Force on approach.


Wait a second. Oheck it out.


- Hey, those are Pollen Jocks!
- Wow.


I've never seen them this close.


They know what it's like
outside the hive.


Yeah, but some don't come back.


- Hey, Jocks!
- Hi, Jocks!


You guys did great!


You're monsters!
You're sky freaks! I love it! I love it!


- I wonder where they were.
- I don't know.


Their day's not planned.


Outside the hive, flying who knows
where, doing who knows what.

I'm not sure if you're aware of the typical human reaction time, but usually it's around 215ms. It can be as low as 80ms in some specific instances when a highly trained athlete is doing a certain task for which they've been trained. I imagine yours was a bit under 215ms since you seem like an ordinary guy, but you were also on high-alert, expecting the possibility of a projectile coming at you. So if we assume your reaction time was around 150ms, then that tells me that bat had to have been going REALLY fast (sorry, but I don't feel like doing the math right now lol).

In the final hit,
- High-speed footage of the impact?
- High-speed footage of the bat failure?
- Why did the bat fail? What was the mode of failure? (appeared to be secondary to the ball impact)


Safety...
- overall... more attention to safety is needed. The kinetic energy of a wayward bat and the potential for penetration (fractured aluminum) are both quite high.
- Barriers for 'pitcher', 'operator', and 'camera' all did not appear adequate.
- Kudos on adding the vibration sensor. Consider adding a second.
- Kudos on adding the pin to connect the two bats. Not ideal, but a good last-minute addition.
- Pinning the apparatus to the ground is advised, as well as weighting the base to make it less susceptible to vibration.
- For high-risk devices, consider adding "dead-man" safeties. e.g. on the main controller, and/or even a dedicated switch/person.
- Did your insurer sign off on that shoot? Woof! :)


General...
- It seems like this project did not get quite as much planning as others. Given the general success so far, a "redo" or "revisit" may be worthwhile.
- Additional high-speed camera angles (add one perpendicular to the flight path, and an overhead angle) to allow for better data collection
- Additional analysis of the data (impact kinetics (ball, primary bat, secondary bat), flight path, machine vibration/harmonics, etc.)
- Could you apply motor-braking (as done with your circular saw project) as a safety feature to the batting machine? In certain failure modes might this be more dangerous than without?
- Yes, I realize that staffing, personal time/schedule limitations, and cost are factors that may rule out "bigger and better." Use the ideas as you see fit.

Everything was great until the aluminum bat came out. Then it all canceled out. Can't break a record with an illegal bat. By the way, I don't think anyone ever hit a ball much over 550 ft.
That said, the new studies in launch angle and exit velocity has changed the game. Extreme impact is what we saw/are seeing now. A perfect example was Daniel Murphy, who was a good line drive hitter. But Murphy always fell just short. What he always had though, was that special intangible that's rare in baseball. The Mets could be down 10 runs with 2 outs and 2 strikes in the 9th. If Dan was at the plate, he'd believe they could still win. He was a rally starter and someone who never gave up. Well, it seems the Mets hired a guy who worked with Dan and Murphy took to this new batting tech like a duck to water. He showed how he was transformed in the 2015 post season. I knew he (in baseball terms) "got it". Some players get whatever their "it" is young, some older and some never. Unfortunately for Murphy, he got his it in the last quarter of his career. The Mets, in their infinite wisdom didnt want to pay Murphy, thinking his change was an aberration. But, nothing could be more wrong and he was sighed by the Nats for what would turn out to be a major bargain for them and went on to play MVP baseball, making his teammate Bryce Harper look silly by comparison. Bottom line: This was all due to Murphy and the new batting theories meshing like Mike Scott and the split finger that saved his career. Many probably thought that Muphy started taking PEDs, but all the evidence was clear, as to what happened. Sadly, had Dan discovered this at 25, he would likely be a first ballot HOFer. That's how amazing it was. Go look him up from 2015 thru 2018. He was an unstoppable force.
Anyway, love the batting machine, just disappointed that you guys used an illegal bat. You may as well have shot the baseball out of a cannon. I suppose it's the fun of the whole thing. I'm probably being way to anal.

Hey Destin:

3:35

When you drew a diagram of the 3 phase voltage, you drew a wavey line on the top of the combined voltage curves to represent the torque of the 3-phase motor.

While this does represent the max-voltage, it's does not represent the torque.
-----------
Due to the construction of motors, the torque is proportional to input voltage, which is a function of either:

In Y configuration - the summed difference between the voltage of each wire and the total combined voltage (combined voltage is 0, so it is essentially compared to ground)

In Delta configuration - the summed difference between each wire voltage compared to the other 2 wires separately

In either case, the total is a constant number.
------------
This is the major advantage of 3 phase over single phase. As the power is a function of the voltage and current (with current being a function of voltage and resistance), power becomes a function of voltage and resistance. This means that with a constant effective voltage, you get a constant effective power.
------------
While the same effect can be reached using DC voltage, the main issue with large-scale DC transmission arrises.

The issue being that, when transferring power long distances over cable, power losses occur. The losses are mainly due to the amount of current passing through the wire. The best way to reduce the neccessary current is to increase the voltage. (P=IV).

This means that in an ideal situation, power would be transmitted long distances at High Voltage and then lowered for use in homes and factories.

Unfortunately, while Direct Current solved the constant power problem, it is not very easy to convert from low voltage to high voltage (or vise-versa)

Alternating current can be easily converted using a transformer, utilizing the magnetic flux created by the coils of wire with AC currents.

This means that we need to properties of each to get the best of both worlds, efficient and constant power.

Three Phase solves both these problems.

-----------------
Credentials:
Currently studying Mechanical Engineering at the University of Waterloo
-----------------
While not all of this information is perfectly accurate, it does help to explain the major advantage of 3 phase power of single phase and DC.

2x the bat speed but only marginally more distance? The HowStuffWorks page on wood vs. aluminum bats  estimates that for every extra MPH of bat speed, a baseball will fly another 8 feet. The mechanics of a batter's swing, the human body's flexibility...who knows what's involved. Mickey Mantle is quoted as having said that the hardest ball he ever hit was on May 22, 1963. That is the famous homerun that came within a foot or two of being the only ball ever hit out of the older Yankee Stadium. When it hit the facade, the ball was 118 feet high and 370 feet from Mickey's bat to the point where it hit the facade. Although the physics of ball flight is not simple, calculations predicted the ball would have traveled 734 feet if it has not been stopped. I watched many games at the old Yankee Stadium. I often sat in the seats below where Mickey's ball hit. Looking up at that facade, it was always inconceivable to me that a human could hit a ball that high and that far. Of course, that assumes Mickey was actually of this planet. 💪😲

I'm not sure I buy the notion that there's no torque at the zero voltage crossover points. The alternations put power into the armature only when the current flows true, but the energy is stored in the inertial flywheel effect. If there was zero torque at the crossovers there'd be an audible 60 hz buzz. Taking this a step further, an internal combustion engine gets it's shaft output power when the fuel burns in pulses, there would be a pronounced vibration felt when no cylinders are firing. Instead, once again there's enough inertial force inherent to the engine design which keeps the power steady throughout the crankshaft rotation. IMHO,YMMV, fwiw, etc.

There are a couple of different ways that you can explore this into much more depth. Are you trying to hit the furthest baseball ever under the most perfect circumstances or under legal MLB requirements? I think it would be fun to do it under perfect circumstances. MLB uses wooden bats which have a significantly lower restitution, mainly to protect the pitcher and other infielders.
So since you mentioned restitution, let’s start with baseball bat regulations. The three most common for highschool, college and some adult leagues are USSSA, BESR, and the most common now BBCOR. USSSA uses a ratio in what they call “Bat Performance Factor” (BPF) of 1.20. Meaning that after the ball makes direct contact with the bat, the exit velocity will be at most 20% more than entry velocity. BESR is an older standard and more sought after for adult leagues with no regulations and you can find some of these bats on eBay for almost $1000 brand new. BESR stands for “Bat Exit Speed Ratio” and measure the combined three: ball entry velocity, ball exit velocity and bat swing speed. It was only after about 8 years bat manufacturing companies were finding ways to insert high quality alloys and composite into many different parts of the baseball bat trying to give it as much “POP” as possible. They quickly found that two-piece bats had some mysterious trampoline effect that one piece bats didn’t and boy did it give the batter more power. And this transitions us into the current baseball bat standard for most non-professional leagues, BBCOR. This stands for Bat-Ball-Coefficient-of-Restitution. On most bars along with this you’ll see the number 0.50. Restitution in physics is generally expressed between 0 (non-elastic) and 1 (perfectly elastic). Most wooden bats have a BBCOR rating around 0.50 and this was established again to level the playing field and protect the players of the game.
My conclusion after explaining all of this, is you want to find a baseball bat that is BESR rated but doesn’t flex like most two-piece bats that you’ll find. I recommend triple alloy bats or full composite bats.
Now that we are done with that, let’s talk about swinging the bat. Your angle was fine for swinging the bat around, at speeds that high. But one major thing that wasn’t taken into consideration was that baseball players to don’t swing the bat straight around. If you look up many videos of baseball players explaining the perfect swing, you’ll notice as they swing they rotate their wrists counter clockwise through their swing thus rotating the barrel of the bat. Doing so allows that batter to make more solid straight-on contact on the ball, while establishing backspin on the exit of the ball from the bat giving it a higher exit velocity and also allowing it to fly higher. If you were able to figure out a way to employ this into your mechanical engineering, this would be game changing for sure. If you have any other questions feel free to message me. I’ve done a great deal of baseball science research throughout my life and love that I’m able to share it with you. Hope you get to see this. Thanks for all of your hard work in your videos. Happy New Year!!!

I don't want to be a crybaby about safety but those first tests using just a door were pretty irresponsible. If it had got a clean hit on the ball I wouldn't be surprised to see the ball go straight through the door in a hail of shrapnel and if it chucked the bat at you then good luck. Sure, the door probably would have slowed the projectile down enough that you might be able to walk away from a direct hit but those splinters don't have to be going very fast to take an eye out or catch an artery.
I get that you obviously can't go carting a precision crafted safety capsule but a few easy to procure items like duvets/floor mats/rugs to spread the impact and catch the bits can really up your chances of coming out in one piece when trying to hide behind a bit of chipboard from fast moving projectiles. Its always better to overdo the safety precautions on the first try because you might not get a second to refine the approach.

Cool experiment though, well done and all the best for the future.

Those numbers just make no sense.  If the bat was moving at 250mph then the exit velocity would have been at least 2x the speed of the fastest major league record, which equates to at least 4x the energy.  So only beating the record by 120-150 ft makes no sense.  I'd suspect it to travel at least 2x as far b/c wind resistance is higher the faster you go, so it's definitely not going to go 4x as far, even with 4x the energy.  But an 17.6% increase in distance with 4x the energy, seems off to me.

Destin - this video is awesome work as always, but as some have noted, please be careful; you joked about how there wasn't enough reaction time to dodge the bat, but as you also noted that plywood offered inadequate protection.

I decided to calculate the forces here to get an idea of how bad this was. An aluminum bat weighs about 32 oz, so 0.907 kg, and the speed at the end of bat was 250 mph, so 111 meters pers second. Kinetic energy is (1/2 * .907) * (111²) = 5,587 joules.

That's more kinetic energy than a 12 gauge shotgun (4,453 joules).

That's well within final episode territory.

I little but important correction to your analysis of three phase supply. Regardless on the number of phases (2 or more) AC motors (ideally) provide constant torque on the shaft given the constant load. Since a part of the current is a magnetization current for the magnetic circuit of the motor, there is always a power factor that is less than 1. However the motor draws constant power from the grid, and output torque is directly dependant on it.

On the other hand 1 phase AC motors try to create 2 phases by using capacitors, but since this can't be achieved ideally the power has some periodic component and is not constant even under constant load.

10:36 I had to rewatch

Your 3 phase explanation at 3:10 is incredibly wrong although is a nice idea.

In single phase you do still get torque at the 0v part of the sin wave because their is magnetic potential energy being converted back into electrical potential energy in the coil windings.

3 phase is more powerful because you are not referencing the voltage to ground (0v), instead the positive voltage is referenced to another phase which will be in negative voltage making the difference much more. You can calculate the average by the amount of phases square rooted, so 3 phase is 3^(1/2) or 1.73 the voltage so 100v at 3 phase would be 173v. At least in a delta configuration.

In a star configuration you simply have more power because you're using 3 more coils meaning you can use 3x the amount of current without overloading the incoming line. Which is why it's not as common in heavy duty applications.

This is the reason why if you reverse any 2 phases at any stage, the direction of the motor will reverse as the positive voltage will be at a different reference in the timescale making the positive section reference to a different negative coil.

I agree that there is "no torque" (magnetic impulse) applied to the motor at zero-crossing voltage. However that does not mean single phase motors have dead spots in their rotational torque. The motor, pulley, and certainly the bat-helicopter setup would continue to rotate due to momentum. Even without any load... you are implying single phase motors rotate unevenly by their nature. That would be bad news for every machine out there that expects vibration free propulsion.

There’s a reason why you “hit with the label up” when using a wooden bat. The manufacturer’s label is applied (to the barrel) of the bat, so that runs parallel to the grain of the wood. Wood’s greatest impact strength is achieved when the impact is perpendicular to the grain of the wood. By hitting the ball with the mfg label facing the sky (or home plate), the grain of the wood is running parallel to both. With this, the ball will impact the wood at the optimum 90 degrees to the grain. You’ll see the same wood grain orientation in wooden handled hammers, axes, and other wooden handled striking tools.

So the four wire thing is ehhhhhhh. You dont NEED four wires, example, a three wave Charging system on a car, the fourth wire is a a whatif wire, Atleast if you're dealing with grounding at the device. In this case you're not, but it's not essential to the concept of three phase power.

Early in the days if industrial motors there was a thing called two phase power to help provide more torque on motors. I don’t know if it was less efficient or just didn’t catch on. There are still parts of Philadelphia and NYC that are supplied by two phase power.

For quick reference:
Your normal house voltage has a single phase supply with two sine waves with opposite polarity in phase with each other. Your normal 120 volt power is only one of those two sine waves.

In two phase power there are phases are 90 degrees out of phase with one another. The way power distribution works you will not see much difference in a residential service, but in industrial equipment applications this is a major difference and specialized motors or larger conductors may be needed.

With three phase power, there are three sine waves 120 degrees out of phase with each other. This is really good as most modern industrial motors are three phase. This still doesn’t affect residential power, but in most commercial and industrial electrical services there will be 208 volts from phase to phase rather than 240 volts. Your normal electrical outlet will still have 120 volts. The explanation for this is a bit complicated, but you are not just measuring from peak to peak of opposite sine waves since they are all out of phase from each other.

PSA: Pre-Statcast home run distances are fish stories. Unless there is solid visual confirmation of the actual spot on the ground a ball landed at, don't believe any home run distance estimate from before Statcast actually tracked batted balls. Commentators used to drop 500+ ft claims all the time on home runs that look exactly like barely exceptional 460 footers. It's just not worth believing.

Hey bud, you could hit it further by creating an acceleration during the duration of contact with much less speed. Simply driving the bat at 200+ mph is only raising the level of mass being driven through the bat and/or ball.

Also, because the bat is not changing direction (which happens when a batter rolls his wrist and creates contact with the ball), all the mass is being mitigated outward, creating centrifugal force which is not being directed at a 90 degree angle(from the plane of the centerline that is going down the length of the bat).

If you notice, when the bat comes out of device you have created here in this video, the bat began traveling nearly exactly along the line I mentioned above. That is because the force from the machine is sending this energy outward from the machines center point of rotation and the bat is in a fixed position aimed 'near' the center point of rotation; Amongst other variables like rotational speed and the resistance of the side winds changing to the upcoming and on coming winds as time moves forward.

If you were to move the mound, or machine closer to 1st base, slowing the pitch slightly and aiming to the left of the centerline of the machines designated center origin of rotation, your machine could make contact between the ball and bat, creating a statistic that is greater than the one just stimulated in this video. I would the ball would be hit towards center field to right field, as opposed to the one just gathered here in left-center field. But that also wouldn't be considered a home run within regulations. It would just be something else.

Just my couple cents.

The main issue with generating light from sound, "sonoluminescence" is that it requires very sensitive frequency modulation of a specific area. The resonant frequency of the liquid you wish to suspend a bubble in must be matched, and then maintained. Then once the bubble is captured the device can be tuned to apply pressure to the bubble. If someone coughs on the outside surface of the container of liquid it can be enough to pop the bubble. Also. Temperature is a non considered variable so far. Both the proper operating temperature of the entire device and the active temperature fluctuations from within the bubble. Apparently the gas inside becomes plasma when squeezed properly on all sides. Plasma In a bubble trapped in resonant frequency matched liquid is Supposedly in excess of 10,000⁰F. The bubble will bounce from this tight plasma state back to "full expansion" and shift from that extreme high temp state to under -250⁰ extreme low state and oscillate between the two until disturbed. So the second issue is how to deal with the super cold temp, and harvest the light, electricity, and heat coming off the plasma

According to Wikipedia baseball bats typically have a mass of ~0.94kg, with two of them spinning here (not including the pulleys and mounts I don’t know the mass of) that’s a mass of 1.88kg, and Destin says the bat has a velocity of 240mph (107.2896m/s).
Kinetic Energy = (½)mv² = ½ x 1.88 x 107.2896 x 107.2896 = 10,820.3948J = 10.8203948KJ
The bats alone have almost 11KJ of energy when spinning at top speed… I didn’t really have a point here, just thought it was interesting.

I doubt ANY wooden bat would hold up during this experiment but a lot of people don't know that a wooden bat has a strong and weak side. Generally, the manufacturers find the strong side of the bat and will index the label brand in such a way that if the batter holds the bat with the brand facing up, the ball will make contact with the strong side.

There's a teachable moment in there about using GPS to measure distances and how to achieve sub meter accuracy.

Your phone can measure down to 1 meter accuracy under the most ideal circumstances but is more often than not 3 meter or wider.

Rtk is how you achieve sub meter. Down to sub centimeter in some cases.

Another interesting topic is how California surveyors benchmarks work when California is constantly moving and fast.

Great video! Got a subscriber. Just some random musings...that Skunk Works book is a good one. I grew up in Palmdale, CA very close to the giant Lockheed building. My grandfather and uncle served, then went into aerospace engineering and both worked on black projects quite a bit. Too late for the SR-71 (which I used to see/hear from my house in the 70s as they would train out of Edwards AFB). They worked on the radar absorbent skin of the B1-B, B2, F-117, as well as the heat dissipating tiles of the Space Shuttles. My uncle also worked on the F-22 before retiring. It’s amazing how much earlier many of these aircraft systems were conceived and mocked up, then built and tested, before the public ever knew a thing. We heard multiple sonic booms most days and I just assumed that everyone did growing up. Lol. About the baseball machine, maybe if you used titanium bats... But seriously even with an aluminum bat going 250 mph, it’s crazy that air friction knocked that ball down short of 700 feet. I’m trying to remember if drag increases at a more than linear rate as an object accelerates. I think you get diminishing returns but I’ll have to look it up. But think about MLB players with wooden bats swinging “only” in the high 90s, being able to crank a ball 550+ feet, or about 80% of what your Batcopter did. Of course, you guys probably never really got hold of one on the sweet spot with the perfect timing and angle. Probably could have cleared 800 feet! Lastly I’m suspicious about those old timey HR records. I have no doubt that the Babe and Mantle absolutely mashed baseballs. But look at some shots by Big Mac and Bonds, among others (yes, juiced as they were). Two HRs that pop into my head are the upper deck shot Bonds hit at Yankee stadium and the ball he hit against the Angels where you can see Tim Salmon saying “that’s the furthest ball I’ve ever seen hit”. Not to mention some of the shots into McCovey cove or that time he annihilated Gagne’s 100 mph high heater. I think that ball might still be in the air! Point is I don’t think MLB wants to count HR distances from the 90s/00s because my eyes and ears tellme quite a few guys exceeded the official records. I played too and as you say the sound of a hit tells you a lot...plus when a ball is just past its apex when it it flies over a 400’ sign...yeah. Anyhoo, again a great video. Appreciate the time you guys put into it and now I’m off to binge some of your other vids! Happy New Year!

Some tips here:
1. Use a slanted wall to hide behind with a lexan sheet to properly deflect the ball. A ball or a bat that hits a wall at 90 degrees can as well penetrate it and cause you to get a lot of wood splinters embedded in your body. Sloped armor is used in tanks for that specific reason.
2. Use a helmet whenever you have things like clubs and bats potentially going into orbit. Even if it don't protect against a direct hit it can protect against splinters and secondary items flying around.

What I remember best about the SR-71 was that they leaked fluids (required fluids like oil), leaked fluids like a sieve.......UNTIL they achieved operational speed. If a Blackbird wasn't leaking on the tarmac, you were getting ready to fly with a damaged plane........NOT a good idea.
Truthfully, this wasn't a fault, in and of itself. The flight speeds of the Blackbird required tolerances in the airframe and engines that accounted for expansion from heat buildup. Heat buildup brought about by those very speeds.
It became a choice. Closer tolerances that preserved operational fluids, BUT also limited the potential of the airframe......OR looser tolerances that allowed leakage, BUT also allowed for maximum speeds.
The choice that was made is quite obvious - the Blackbird leaks like a sieve.
